misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once the scores array is sorted, the names array will still line up so that the element at index n-1 in names is the name of the student with the highest score, even though the names array was never rearranged.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, each array is an independent data structure. Sorting one array (z or its alias w) only reorders the elements of that array; the runtime has no knowledge that another array (y) is conceptually "paired" with it. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must explicitly move elements in both arrays using the same swaps or, alternatively, avoid sorting and just track the index of the maximum score. The student's code assumes that the logical pairing of names and scores is maintained automatically after sorting, which is not how array operations work.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output (name does not match the highest score)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a parallel structure (the scores array, z) is sufficient to find the maximum value, and that the original index-based association with the names array (y) will somehow hold, or they overlook the necessity of swapping elements in the names array simultaneously.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that array manipulation functions like `Arrays.sort()` modify the elements within only the specified array object. When parallel arrays are used to link related data (names and scores by index), any operation that changes the order of one array requires a corresponding, manual synchronization (swapping) of elements in all partner arrays to maintain data integrity.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output (associates the highest score with the wrong student name)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(w) on an array reference will sort that array, and that sorting a copy of the scores array will automatically update which index contains the highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() modifies the array in-place. More critically, they create a reference `w` pointing to the same array as `z` (the original scores), sort it, but then use the original array indices to look up values. Since they sort the scores but do NOT sort the corresponding names in parallel, the index of the highest score no longer corresponds to the correct student name. Additionally, after sorting, they access `z[k]` and `y[k]` at the last index, which will give a mismatched pair.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program outputs the wrong student name paired with the highest score, or outputs data from the wrong index position because the parallel arrays are not kept in sync during sorting.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting the scores array, the highest score will always be at index n-1, and that the name at index n-1 in the names array will correspond to whoever has that highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not recognize that sorting only one of two parallel arrays breaks the correspondence between indices. When the scores array is sorted, the name at the same index in the names array is no longer the name of the student with the score at that index. The student would need to either: (1) sort both arrays together (using a custom comparator or manual index tracking), or (2) track the original index of the maximum value before sorting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program prints the name of a different student than the one with the highest score.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that assigning `int[] w = z;` creates a separate copy of the array that can be sorted independently without affecting the original.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `int[] w = z;` creates another reference to the same array object in memory, not a copy. Both `w` and `z` point to the same underlying array. When `Arrays.sort(w)` is called, it sorts the actual array that both variables reference. The student likely intended to create a copy using `int[] w = z.clone();` or `System.arraycopy()`, but did not.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Both `z` and `w` now point to a sorted array, so the original ordering is lost. The names array remains unsorted, creating a mismatch.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting only one
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the last index, then the name at that same index in the names array will still be the correct student for that score, even though they never moved any elements in the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are just independent sequences of values. When you call Arrays.sort on the scores array, Java only reorders the elements in that one array. It has no knowledge of any intended relationship to another array, so it does not and cannot move elements in the names array to keep them matched with their scores. To keep names and scores aligned, the program must explicitly move the corresponding name whenever a score is moved, or use a single data structure (e.g., a Student object) that is sorted as a unit.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output: the printed name is the last one entered, not necessarily the one with the highest score

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Thinking array assignment makes a new independent copy
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student likely believes that writing `int[] w = z;` creates a new, separate array `w` that contains a copy of the same scores as `z`. Under this belief, sorting `w` would not change `z` at all; instead, `w` would be the sorted version and `z` would stay in its original order.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are reference types. The variable `z` holds a reference (pointer) to an array object. The statement `int[] w = z;` copies that reference, not the contents of the array. After this assignment, both `w` and `z` point to the same underlying array object. Calling `Arrays.sort(w)` rearranges the elements of that single array, so `z` sees the sorted order as well. To get an independent copy, the student would need to explicitly copy the elements, e.g., with `w = Arrays.copyOf(z, z.length);`.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: potential logical confusion about why sorting `w` also changes `z` (even though in this specific code they do not exploit `w` afterward)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `w` array (which references the scores array `z`) in line 35 automatically causes the corresponding parallel array `y` (names) to be sorted simultaneously, thus maintaining the paired integrity of the data.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Sorting an array using `Arrays.sort()` modifies only that array's elements based on its values. When parallel arrays are used, sorting one array (scores) requires manually tracking and simultaneously swapping the corresponding elements in the other array (names) to keep the data linked. Variables that point to the same array (like `w = z`) do not somehow link actions on them to other unrelated arrays (like `y`).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program prints the score of the top student correctly (since the scores array `z` is sorted), but pairs it with the name that was originally present at that index before the sort, leading to mismatched name/score output for the 'Top student'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that declaring a new variable `w` assigned to `z` (line 34) is necessary or conceptually useful before calling `Arrays.sort(w)`, perhaps thinking `Arrays.sort()` requires a temporary variable or that the sort operation on `w` yields a new sorted copy without modifying the original scores array `z`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, an assignment like `int[] w = z;` creates two different reference variables pointing to the exact same array object in memory. Sorting using `Arrays.sort(w)` modifies the array object itself, meaning the scores stored in `z` are sorted in place. Introducing `w` adds unnecessary complexity and does not create a copy.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None (this code segment works, but reflects a poor understanding of array referencing vs. copying).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array (z) is sufficient to identify the top student. They think that after sorting in ascending order, the last element z[n-1] will be the highest score AND y[n-1] will be the corresponding name.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has failed to understand that parallel arrays maintain correspondence through index positions. When you sort one array (z), the other array (y) is NOT automatically rearranged to maintain the original pairing. The student has sorted the scores but left the names array in its original order, breaking the name-score correspondence.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program will print the name of the student at position n-1 paired with the highest score, which is incorrect. For example, with input (Alice=85, Bob=92, Charlie=78), after sorting scores [78, 85, 92], the code prints y[2]='Charlie' with z[2]=92, but Charlie's actual score is 78.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student creates a new variable `w` and assigns `z` to it, perhaps believing this creates a separate copy of the array. They may think sorting `w` won't affect the original `z`, or conversely, they may be unaware that `w` and `z` point to the same array in memory.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `int[] w = z;` creates an alias (reference), not a copy. Both variables point to the same array object. Sorting `w` directly modifies `z`. The student's intention seems unclear—either they wanted a copy (requiring `Arrays.copyOf(z, z.length)`) or they didn't realize the mutation would occur.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Logical confusion: The extra variable `w` serves no functional purpose and suggests misunderstanding of reference semantics. While the code happens to work (since sorting z is what's needed), it indicates flawed mental model of how arrays are passed/stored.
